CO-EDS RULED
OUT OF CAMPUS
ACTIVITIES HERE
Students' Activities Council
Makes Ruling Following
Election of Miss Howser
SEAL AW ARDS WILL
BE MADE ONLY ONCE
28 Varsity Seals, 2 7 Certificates Awarded By Undergraduate Council
No woman will be permitted in
the future to hold membership in
any activity on the campus represented in the Students' Activities
Council, it was ruled by that undergraduate body which governs student activities at the Johns Hopkins University.
This move was taken following
objections from activity heads, students, alumni, and faculty members to the election of Miss Margaret Howser, a College for Teachers student in her third year, to the
editor-in-chief's post of the Black
and Blue Jay, campus magazine.
Miss Howser has been a member
of the editorial staff of the publication since February, 1931. The
Students' Activities Council was in
no position, following her election,
to protest officially or to demand
her immediate resignation due to
the fact that the group's constitution made no statement as to a
,......1
heading a campus activity.
~t was definitely established that
the College for Teachers is not regarded as part of the regular undergraduate department at the Hopkins.

p:w

Change In Seal Awards
The Council, headed by Kenneth
Sharretts, has decided that beginning in the next academic year
Varsity Seals will be awarded only
once each year to only eligible
seniors. December, previous to the
closing of the University for the
Christmas holidays, was set as the
definite time for the awarding of
the emblems· given in recognition
of outstanding work in campus activities represented in the Council.
Previously, the group awarded
seals to seniors some time between
December and February and to
juniors in the latter part of April.
Award Seals
Varsity Seals and certificates
were given by the Council to the
following:

THE JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY, HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 26, 1932

Huang, Grad Student,
Tours Southern
Universities
T. Young Huang, a graduate student at the Hopkins in Economics,
has for the last several weeks been
touring the South and speaking at
a number of institutions on his
itinerary concerning the present
strained relations between his
country and Japan.
One of his recent stops was the
Tuske~ee Institute in Alabama,
where he addressed an audience of
about 2,000 people. Among his
other stops are the Southern College in Birmingham, and the WOman's College of Alabama, as weff
as numerous colleges in North and
South Carolina.

CAMPUS IS ASKED
TO BACK OLYMPIC
FUNDS CAMPAIGN
Committee Requests At Least
Ten Cents From Each
Student
IDDINS TO MANAGE
OLYMPIC TEAM
Sharretts, Committee Chairman, Asks Support To
Show Appreciation
In order that the expenses of the
1932 Olympics may not fall too
heavily on any one group of people,
the Olympic Games Committee has
asked the committee in charge of
lacrosse to make some plan whereby money may be raised. The plan
evolved is for each college participating in the lacrosse tournament
to attempt to raise enough money
to cover expenses of one Olympic
athlete.
At Least 'Ten Cents Asked
It has been declared, '¥ith peFmission from the proper authorities, to ask each Hopkins ma;; to
make a contribution to the fund of
at least ten cents, and more if so
desired. Those directing the campaign for funds believe that this
will be a burden to no one at all,
and will certainly be of great benefit to the Olympic Committee.
Kenneth C. Sharretts has been
placed in charge of the work on the
campus, and he reports that in a
few days plans for the campaign
will be complete. Men of his committee will be supplied with envelopes .with which to collect the
contributions, and lists of men to
see. The results of the campaign
will be published as soon as the
University has been completely
Sharretts has asked
canvassed.
that each student "keep himself
supplied with plenty of dimes, and
if these are not available, quarters
will not be objectionable."
Turnbull Chairman
The committee for this work will
necessarily be large, and it is desired
that each man asked to serve 011
the committee wm cooperate to the
best of his ability. Jack Turnbull
has been appointed chairman of the
group to canvass the engineernig
students.
Hopkins ha~ been signally honored by having Henry Iddins, its business manager, selected to manage
whatever team is chosen to represent the United States in lacrosse.
"It is therefore up to us," Sharretts
added, "to show our appreciation by
supporting the above outlined plan."

TEO WEEMSNINE ELEC·TED
IS BOOKED FOR TO HONORARY
SENIOR BALL HOPKINS FRATS
Big Event Of June Week To
Be Held June 10 At
Alcazar Ballroom
KNEIP URGES SENIORS
TO PAY CLASS DUES
Arrangements Being Made
For Other Features Of
Annual June Week
Ted
Weems'
internationally
known orchestra has been booked
to play at the Senior Ball, to be
staged during June Week, on June
10, at the Alcazar Ballroom, it was
announced by Walter Kneip, chairman of June Week Committee.
At present the 15-piece band is
playing in Chicago and is broadcasting nightly over WGN, of that
city. Weems' orchestra will make
a tour of the South in June, it was
learned today. Ted Weems himself will preside as master of ceremonies at the Ball, introducing the
specialty numbers and leading the
orchestra which has attained worldwide prominence.
Among the
orchestra's vocalists are Country
W ashburne, Parker Gibbs, Red
Ingles, and Elmo Tanner.
Well-Known Orchestra
One of the best known bands in
the country, it has provided the
syncopation for more college proms
than any other orchestra .
Kneip said today that the niteclub party will be held al the
L'Hirondelle Club and the beach
party, at Magna Vista, on dates to
be selected by the June Week Committee later. The Cotillon Board
is planning to bring a nationally
known band here to play at the
last cotil!on. In the past only local
orchestras have played at this
feature of June Week.
Urges Payment of Dues
In speaking of the Week, Kneip
said today that it is imperative that
all seniors pay up their class dues
at once as funds are needed by the
committee to continue work on the
annual event. May 1 has been set
as the final day for the payment of
the $25 class dues which should be
paid to John Meyers at the postoffice in Gilman Hall.
Tickets for June Week will be
put on sale soon, said K~eip. The
subscription to the Ball at which
Weems' orchestra will play will be
$7.50. For the complete Week the
price will be only $12.50.
In addition . to Kneip the committee includes Gutman, Levy,
Kahl, Dukehart, Quick, and Henderson.

Two Hopkins Students
Awarded Athens
Fellowships
Two students of the Hopkins
Archaeology Department were
awarded fellowships at Athens for
next year, it was recently announced by Dr. David Moore Robinson, W. H. Collins Vickers, Professor of Archaeology. Gladys
Davidson and Edward Fluck were
the .recipients of these awards,
which are the twelfth and thirteenth
to be given students of Dr. Robinson during the time he has been at
the Hopkins.
The fellowships were awarded
after a series of seven examinations
-in various subjects given to a group
from universities all over the
country. Each fellowship is worth
$1,400 to the holder.

Tau Beta Pi elected Henry Whitby,
'32; Thomas Clayton Crane, John
Nicholas Fehrer, and Robert William Reynolds, of the class of '33.
Kouwenhoven Speaks
Mr. William B. Kouwenhoven,
associate professor in the Engineering School, announced the elections
to Tau Beta Pi. He brought to the
attention of the student body the
fact that this year marks the twentieth anniversary of the Engineering
School at the Hopkins.
Mr. Leilich, who is a member of
the oldest chapter of Tau Beta Pi,
at Lehigh University, told of some
of his experiences as a,n engineer,
and pointed out some of the difficulties encountered by engineers.
Founded In 1916
Omicron Delta Kappa, one of
the earlier and more unique societies
of the country, was originated at
Washington and Lee University by
Carl Fisher, who, working with
fellow students, devised a new fraternity which would give outstanding distinction to deserving members of the college. The Beta chapfer was established at the Hopkins
in 1916. Membership in 0. D. K.
has been vo~ed for several years
the highest honor on the Hopkins
campus by graduating classes. Only
three per cent of the undergraduate
enrollment is eligible for election.

Frolic In Evening
--Arrangements have been completed by the Cotillion Board to
have Ted Brownagle, voted the
most popular orchestra in Delaware
at the Musical Artists Convention
in 1931, to play for the Army
Week-end frolic, which will be held
at the Hotel Belvedere, Saturday
from 10 P. M. to 2 A. M.
During the winter months,
Brownagle and his eleven artists
entertained at the Hotel DuPont,
Delaware, and are booked for the
Hotel Henlopen, Rehobeth Beach,
this coming summer. They are
highly recommended by Georgetown, University of Delaware, and
Cornell, having played one or two
engagements at each of these colleges this past winter.
Combination tickets are on sale
in Levering Hall, $2.50. These
tickets will include one admission
to the Army game, one couple to
the tea dance, featuring Jules Penrose and his band, and one couple
to the frolic .Saturday evening.

Engineers To Make Artificial
Lightning At Public Display
Apparatus used by the various
engineering schools will be collected
in a novel display sponsored by the
mechanical, civil and electrict engineers at the Hopkins on the sixth
and seventh of May, Mr. W. B.
Kouwenhoven announced recently.
Lightning Machine Obtained
Mr. Kouwenhoven has negotiated
the loan of an artificial lightning
machine from the Westinghouse
Company for the display. This
laboratory model consists of seventeen condensers which are charged
in parallel with 13,000 volts. These
same condensers are then discharged in series, which brings the
total potential in the neighborhood

devices will be shown, it is said.
Prof. Thompson of the civil engineering department will detl}onstrate a model impact machine such
as is used for testing highways.
Prof. Christie intends to display a
new type smoke recorder. A model
of the Holland Tunnel of New
York will be used in this display.
Second Of Its Kind
The purpose of the demonstrations, Mr. Kouwenhoven said, is to
give the public a general idea of
what the Engineering School is doing. This show will be the second
of its kind ever attempted at Hopkins. The first was held in 1924
and proved to be worth while as
well as successful.
Freshman and sophomore engineering students will act as guides
for those who are unfamiliar with

Dr. Irving Langmuir, winner of
the $10,000 popular science award
for important contributions to
science spoke here last Friday as
one of the lecturers in the Dohme
series. In his exposition of the
"Laws of Adsorption," the physicist
elaborated the older theory into a
new and more general concept,
which he supported by experimental
data.
Disowns Formula
In discussing the use of the
formula which bears his name, the
"Langmuir adsorption isotherm,"
Dr. Langmuir protested that he had
not developed this formula himself,
but merely taken it from previous
work and applied it in a special
case. The formula is used in determining the force of attraction in
certain cases of adsorption.
One of the adsorptive phenomena
which Dr. Langmuir's theory explains is the tremendous force with
which tungsten holds oxygen. At a
temperature of 1,800 degrees absolute it would take three and onehalf years to completely vaporize
the surface layer of oxygen molecules, he explained. The industrially important silica jel, an incompletely dehydrated silicic acid developed by Dr. Patrick here at the
Hopkins also depends upon the adsorption phenomenon for its efficiency.
---o---

M. E. Krah!, holder of the Eli
Lilly Company felowship, and R.
\V. Cairns, holder of the Firestone
Tire and Rubber Company fellowship will report to the conference
in detail upon their researches to
date.
Conduct Informal Tour
A visiting tour of the research
laboratories of the fellows, together
with informal inspection and discussion of their work, will supplement the more formal reports.
At the afternoon session the Hon.
Francis P. Garvan, president of
The Chemical Foundation, Inc., and
donor of several national fellowships, will preside as chairman. The
conference will include a report on
activities arising out of the recommendations of the previous conf erences and a discussion of the
present achievements and future
possibilities of the National Fellowship Plan.

No woman will be permitted in
the future to hold membership in
any activity on the campus represented in the Students' Activities
Council, it was ruled by that undergraduate body which governs student activities at the Johns Hopkins University.
This move was taken following
objections from activity heads, students, alumni, and faculty members to the election of Miss Margaret Howser, a College for Teachers student in her third year, to the
editor-in-chief's post of the Black
and Blue Jay, campus magazine.
Miss Howser has been a member
of the editorial staff of the publication since February, 1931. The
Students' Activities Council was in
no position, following her election,
to protest officially or to demand
her immediate resignation due to
the fact that the group's constitution made no statement as to a
,......1
heading a campus activity.
~t was definitely established that
the College for Teachers is not regarded as part of the regular undergraduate department at the Hopkins.

Huang, Grad Student,
Tours Southern
Universities
T. Young Huang, a graduate student at the Hopkins in Economics,
has for the last several weeks been
touring the South and speaking at
a number of institutions on his
itinerary concerning the present
strained relations between his
country and Japan.
One of his recent stops was the
Tuske~ee Institute in Alabama,
where he addressed an audience of
about 2,000 people. Among his
other stops are the Southern College in Birmingham, and the WOman's College of Alabama, as weff
as numerous colleges in North and
South Carolina.

CAMPUS IS ASKED
TO BACK OLYMPIC
FUNDS CAMPAIGN
Committee Requests At Least
Ten Cents From Each
Student
IDDINS TO MANAGE
OLYMPIC TEAM
Sharretts, Committee Chairman, Asks Support To
Show Appreciation
In order that the expenses of the
1932 Olympics may not fall too
heavily on any one group of people,
the Olympic Games Committee has
asked the committee in charge of
lacrosse to make some plan whereby money may be raised. The plan
evolved is for each college participating in the lacrosse tournament
to attempt to raise enough money
to cover expenses of one Olympic
athlete.
At Least 'Ten Cents Asked
It has been declared, '¥ith peFmission from the proper authorities, to ask each Hopkins ma;; to
make a contribution to the fund of
at least ten cents, and more if so
desired. Those directing the campaign for funds believe that this
will be a burden to no one at all,
and will certainly be of great benefit to the Olympic Committee.
Kenneth C. Sharretts has been
placed in charge of the work on the
campus, and he reports that in a
few days plans for the campaign
will be complete. Men of his committee will be supplied with envelopes .with which to collect the
contributions, and lists of men to
see. The results of the campaign
will be published as soon as the
University has been completely
Sharretts has asked
canvassed.
that each student "keep himself
supplied with plenty of dimes, and
if these are not available, quarters
will not be objectionable."
Turnbull Chairman
The committee for this work will
necessarily be large, and it is desired
that each man asked to serve 011
the committee wm cooperate to the
best of his ability. Jack Turnbull
has been appointed chairman of the
group to canvass the engineernig
students.
Hopkins ha~ been signally honored by having Henry Iddins, its business manager, selected to manage
whatever team is chosen to represent the United States in lacrosse.
"It is therefore up to us," Sharretts
added, "to show our appreciation by
supporting the above outlined plan."

KNEIP URGES SENIORS

Arrangements Being Made
For Other Features Of
Annual June Week
Ted
Weems'
internationally
known orchestra has been booked
to play at the Senior Ball, to be
staged during June Week, on June
10, at the Alcazar Ballroom, it was
announced by Walter Kneip, chairman of June Week Committee.
At present the 15-piece band is
playing in Chicago and is broadcasting nightly over WGN, of that
city. Weems' orchestra will make
a tour of the South in June, it was
learned today. Ted Weems himself will preside as master of ceremonies at the Ball, introducing the
specialty numbers and leading the
orchestra which has attained worldwide prominence.
Among the
orchestra's vocalists are Country
W ashburne, Parker Gibbs, Red
Ingles, and Elmo Tanner.
Well-Known Orchestra
One of the best known bands in
the country, it has provided the
syncopation for more college proms
than any other orchestra .
Kneip said today that the niteclub party will be held al the
L'Hirondelle Club and the beach
party, at Magna Vista, on dates to
be selected by the June Week Committee later. The Cotillon Board
is planning to bring a nationally
known band here to play at the
last cotil!on. In the past only local
orchestras have played at this
feature of June Week.
Urges Payment of Dues
In speaking of the Week, Kneip
said today that it is imperative that
all seniors pay up their class dues
at once as funds are needed by the
committee to continue work on the
annual event. May 1 has been set
as the final day for the payment of
the $25 class dues which should be
paid to John Meyers at the postoffice in Gilman Hall.
Tickets for June Week will be
put on sale soon, said K~eip. The
subscription to the Ball at which
Weems' orchestra will play will be
$7.50. For the complete Week the
price will be only $12.50.
In addition . to Kneip the committee includes Gutman, Levy,
Kahl, Dukehart, Quick, and Henderson.

country. Each fellowship is worth

Kouwenhoven Speaks
Mr. William B. Kouwenhoven,
associate professor in the Engineering School, announced the elections
to Tau Beta Pi. He brought to the
attention of the student body the
fact that this year marks the twentieth anniversary of the Engineering
School at the Hopkins.
Mr. Leilich, who is a member of
the oldest chapter of Tau Beta Pi,
at Lehigh University, told of some
of his experiences as a,n engineer,
and pointed out some of the difficulties encountered by engineers.
Founded In 1916
Omicron Delta Kappa, one of
the earlier and more unique societies
of the country, was originated at
Washington and Lee University by
Carl Fisher, who, working with
fellow students, devised a new fraternity which would give outstanding distinction to deserving members of the college. The Beta chapfer was established at the Hopkins
in 1916. Membership in 0. D. K.
has been vo~ed for several years
the highest honor on the Hopkins
campus by graduating classes. Only
three per cent of the undergraduate
enrollment is eligible for election.

Frolic In Evening
--Arrangements have been completed by the Cotillion Board to
have Ted Brownagle, voted the
most popular orchestra in Delaware
at the Musical Artists Convention
in 1931, to play for the Army
Week-end frolic, which will be held
at the Hotel Belvedere, Saturday
from 10 P. M. to 2 A. M.
During the winter months,
Brownagle and his eleven artists
entertained at the Hotel DuPont,
Delaware, and are booked for the
Hotel Henlopen, Rehobeth Beach,
this coming summer. They are
highly recommended by Georgetown, University of Delaware, and
Cornell, having played one or two
engagements at each of these colleges this past winter.
Combination tickets are on sale
in Levering Hall, $2.50. These
tickets will include one admission
to the Army game, one couple to
the tea dance, featuring Jules Penrose and his band, and one couple
to the frolic .Saturday evening.

Engineers To Make Artificial
Lightning At Public Display
Apparatus used by the various
engineering schools will be collected
in a novel display sponsored by the
mechanical, civil and electrict engineers at the Hopkins on the sixth
and seventh of May, Mr. W. B.
Kouwenhoven announced recently.
Lightning Machine Obtained
Mr. Kouwenhoven has negotiated
the loan of an artificial lightning
machine from the Westinghouse
Company for the display. This
laboratory model consists of seventeen condensers which are charged
in parallel with 13,000 volts. These
same condensers are then discharged in series, which brings the

Many other equally interesting
devices will be shown, it is said.
Prof. Thompson of the civil engineering department will detl}onstrate a model impact machine such

Prof. Christie intends to display a

Second Of Its Kind
The purpose of the demonstrations, Mr. Kouwenhoven said, is to
give the public a general idea of
what the Engineering School is doing. This show will be the second
of its kind ever attempted at Hopkins. The first was held in 1924
and proved to be worth while as
well as successful.
Freshman and sophomore engineering students will act as guides
for those who are unfamiliar with

"Hello, Hawaii"
Bringing Hawaii within speaking distance
of the United States is one of the latest
achievements of the Bell System in its pro·
gram of telephone service extension.
Five years ago the United States had telephone connection only with Canada, Cuba,
and the Mexican border. • Since then, Bell
engineers have so developed radio telephony
that handling calls to Europe, South America,

Australia, Bermuda, Samoa, and Hawaii is
daily routine. Today more than 31,000,000
telephones can be reached - approximately
92% of all the telephones in the world!
Making the telephone practically worldwide in reach promotes understanding between nations. It has far reaching effects commercially and politically. That's what puts
the thrill into such Bell System pioneering.

EXHIBITION

AT HOTEL EMERSON,
FRIDAY, APRIL 29th,
HARRY SCHEIN; Rep. '

FIFTH AVENUE AT FORTY.SIXTH STREET

Dr. Irving Langmuir, winner of
the $10,000 popular science award
for important contributions to
science spoke here last Friday as
one of the lecturers in the Dohme
series. In his exposition of the
"Laws of Adsorption," the physicist
elaborated the older theory into a
new and more general concept,
which he supported by experimental
data.
Disowns Formula
In discussing the use of the
formula which bears his name, the
"Langmuir adsorption isotherm,"
Dr. Langmuir protested that he had
not developed this formula himself,
but merely taken it from previous
work and applied it in a special
case. The formula is used in determining the force of attraction in
certain cases of adsorption.
One of the adsorptive phenomena
which Dr. Langmuir's theory explains is the tremendous force with
which tungsten holds oxygen. At a
temperature of 1,800 degrees absolute it would take three and onehalf years to completely vaporize
the surface layer of oxygen molecules, he explained. The industrially important silica jel, an incompletely dehydrated silicic acid developed by Dr. Patrick here at the
Hopkins also depends upon the adsorption phenomenon for its efficiency.

A visiting tour of the research

The Chemical Foundation, Inc., and
donor of several national fellowships, will preside as chairman. The
conference will include a report on
activities arising out of the recommendations of the previous conf erences and a discussion of the
present achievements and future
possibilities of the National Fellowship Plan.
